Sure, let's create the VPython animation to illustrate the horizontal projectile motion experiment as described. Here is the code implementation:

```python
from vpython import *
import time

# Screen Settings
scene = canvas(width=700, height=400)

# Cyber Input Variable Mapping
Height_I = 5  # initial_height

# Constants
g = vector(0, -9.81, 0)  # acceleration due to gravity

# Objects
ground = box(pos=vector(0, -Height_I, 0), size=vector(20, 0.1, 5), color=color.green)
ball = sphere(pos=vector(-10, Height_I, 0), radius=0.5, color=color.red, make_trail=True)

# Parameters
initial_height = Height_I
initial_velocity = 10
time_step = 0.01

# Initial Conditions
ball.velocity = vector(initial_velocity, 0, 0)
ball.acceleration = g

# Animation Loop
while True:
    ball.pos.x += ball.velocity.x * time_step
    ball.velocity += ball.acceleration * time_step
    
    if ball.pos.x >= 10:
        ball.velocity.x *= -1  # Change direction upon hitting the right wall
    
    if ball.pos.y <= ground.pos.y + ground.size.y:
        ball.velocity.y *= -1  # Bounce off the ground
        ball.pos.y = ground.pos.y + ground.size.y
    
    time.sleep(time_step)
```

This code creates a VPython animation of a ball launched horizontally from an initial height with an initial velocity. The ball accelerates due to gravity and bounces off the ground elastically. The animation will run continuously, simulating the motion of the ball.

The initial height can be updated by changing the value of `Height_I`, which will cause the animation to rerun with the updated initial height.
